xxl.core.cursors.joins
Class SortMergeSymmetricSelfJoin

java.lang.Object
  xxl.core.cursors.AbstractCursor
      xxl.core.cursors.joins.SortMergeSymmetricSelfJoin
All Implemented Interfaces:
Iterator, Cursor
public class SortMergeSymmetricSelfJoin
extends AbstractCursor

A sort-merge implementation of the self-join operator for symmetric join predicates.

Since:
1.1
See Also:
SortMergeJoin, SortMergeSelfJoin

selfJoinPredicate

protected Predicate selfJoinPredicate
Unary predicate determining if a tuple joins with itself.

queryObject

protected Object queryObject
An element of one of the input iteration that is actually used for querying the sweep-area of the other input iteration.

newResult

protected Function newResult
A function that is invoked on each qualifying tuple before it is returned to the caller concerning a call to the next method. This binary function works like a kind of factory method modelling the resulting object (tuple).

results

protected Iterator results
An iterator holding the precomputed results of the join operator. Because the query method of sweep-area returns an iterator of elements that match the given query, this iterator must be stored to return the remaining elements later.

lastResult

protected Object lastResult
Last Object obtained from results which has to be returned for the symmetric case.

self

protected boolean self
Flag indicating if the last object from the input has joins with itself and has not yet been returned.

Constructor Detail

SortMergeSymmetricSelfJoin

public SortMergeSymmetricSelfJoin(Iterator sortedInput,
                                  SweepArea sweepArea,
                                  Predicate selfJoinPredicate,
                                  Function newResult)
Creates a new sort-merge self-join operator backed on a sorted input iterations using the given sweep-area to store the input iterations' elements and probe for join results. Furthermore a function named newResult can be specified that is invoked on each qualifying tuple before it is returned to the caller concerning a call to the next method. This function is a kind of factory method to model the resulting object.

Precondition: The input iteration have to be sorted!

Precondition: The join has to be symmetric

The result-tuples created by this operator are represented as an array of the input iterations' elements that are participated in this join result. If the user wants to specify a different result-type, a mapping function newResult can be specified. This function works like a kind of factory method modelling the resulting object (tuple). The iterator given to this constructor is wrapped to a cursor.

Parameters:
sortedInput - the sorted input iteration to be joined.
sweepArea - the sweep-area used for storing elements of the sorted input iteration (sortedInput).
selfJoinPredicate - unary predicate determining if a tuple joins with itself * @param newResult a factory method (function) that takes two parameters as argument and is invoked on each tuple where the predicate's evaluation result is true, i.e., on each qualifying tuple before it is returned to the caller concerning a call to the next method.

SortMergeSymmetricSelfJoin

public SortMergeSymmetricSelfJoin(Iterator input,
                                  Function newSorter,
                                  SweepArea sweepArea,
                                  Predicate selfJoinPredicate,
                                  Function newResult)
Creates a new sort-merge self-join operator backed on a sorted input iterations using the given sweep-area to store the input iterations' elements and probe for join results. Furthermore a function named newResult can be specified that is invoked on each qualifying tuple before it is returned to the caller concerning a call to the next method. This function is a kind of factory method to model the resulting object. The constructor does not require the input iteration to be sorted. The specified, unary function newSorter will be invoked on the input iteration in order to get a sorted input.

Precondition: The join has to be symmetric

The result-tuples created by this operator are represented as an array of the input iterations' elements that are participated in this join result. If the user wants to specify a different result-type, a mapping function newResult can be specified. This function works like a kind of factory method modelling the resulting object (tuple). The iterator given to this constructor is wrapped to a cursor.

Parameters:
input - the input iteration to be joined.
newSorter - an unary function that sorts the input iteration
sweepArea - the sweep-area used for storing elements of the sorted input iteration (sortedInput).
selfJoinPredicate - unary predicate determining if a tuple joins with itself
newResult - a factory method (function) that takes two parameters as argument and is invoked on each tuple where the predicate's evaluation result is true, i.e., on each qualifying tuple before it is returned to the caller concerning a call to the next method.
Method Detail

open

public void open()
Opens the join operator, i.e., signals the cursor to reserve resources, open the input iteration, etc. Before a cursor has been opened calls to methods like next or peek are not guaranteed to yield proper results. Therefore open must be called before a cursor's data can be processed. Multiple calls to open do not have any effect, i.e., if open was called the cursor remains in the state opened until its close method is called.

Note, that a call to the open method of a closed cursor usually does not open it again because of the fact that its state generally cannot be restored when resources are released respectively files are closed.

Specified by:
open in interface Cursor
Overrides:
open in class AbstractCursor

close

public void close()
Closes the cursor, i.e., signals the cursor to clean up resources, close input iterations and sweep-areas, etc. When a cursor has been closed calls to methods like next or peek are not guaranteed to yield proper results. Multiple calls to close do not have any effect, i.e., if close was called the cursor remains in the state closed.

Note, that a closed cursor usually cannot be opened again because of the fact that its state generally cannot be restored when resources are released respectively files are closed.

Specified by:
close in interface Cursor
Overrides:
close in class AbstractCursor

hasNextObject

protected boolean hasNextObject()
Returns true if the iteration has more elements. (In other words, returns true if next or peek would return an element rather than throwing an exception.)

Specified by:
hasNextObject in class AbstractCursor
Returns:
true if the cursor has more elements.

nextObject

protected Object nextObject()
Returns the next element in the iteration. This element will be accessible by some of the cursor's methods, e.g., update or remove, until a call to next or peek occurs. This is calling next or peek proceeds the iteration and therefore its previous element will not be accessible any more.

Specified by:
nextObject in class AbstractCursor
Returns:
the next element in the iteration.

reset

public void reset()
           throws UnsupportedOperationException
Resets the sort-merge join operator to its initial state such that the caller is able to traverse the join result again without constructing a new join operator (optional operation).

Note, that this operation is optional and might not work for all cursors.

Specified by:
reset in interface Cursor
Overrides:
reset in class AbstractCursor
Throws:
UnsupportedOperationException - if the reset operation is not supported by the cursor.

supportsReset

public boolean supportsReset()
Returns true if the reset operation is supported by the sort-merge join operator. Otherwise it returns false.

Specified by:
supportsReset in interface Cursor
Overrides:
supportsReset in class AbstractCursor
Returns:
true if the reset operation is supported by the sort-merge join operator, otherwise false.

toString

public String toString()
Returns a string representation of the object. In general, the toString method returns a string that "textually represents" this object. The result should be a concise but informative representation that is easy for a person to read. It is recommended that all subclasses override this method.

Overrides:
toString in class Object
Returns:
string representation of the object.
